title: Governing Dynamics: Ignore the Blonde - A Beautiful Mind (3/11) Movie CLIP (2001) HD

comments.text:
While intriguing, many of these comments ignore the point of the story: 
this was the moment of discovery in the real world of social companionship 
and competition--in essence a tutorial in how the mind frames reality in a 
global metaphor, then induces theory from it.﻿
comments.author: Robert Fee

comments.text:
The best result will come from everyone in the group doing what's best for 
himself and the group.﻿

comments.text:
+Cesar Faz You're using the term "natural selection" incorrectly. As 
natural selection doesn't have any desirable or non desirable traits. The 
traits act on the environment of the species which weeds certain organisms 
out. What you're referring to is a form of Eugenics, which every human 
practices. Everyone looks at each other and sees certain traits that fit 
their ideal of a healthy or beautiful person. It's similar to our forced 
eugenics/selective breeding on dogs where we mate certain dogs together in 
order to achieve a dog with a certain trait. It's selective breeding at 
it's finest. Keep in mind this really is not all that natural, as the 
traits that are found healthy or desirable are arbitrary and culturally 
based, there is no ideal human outside your own culture. I also fail to see 
what this has to do with Communism. Not a good idea to compare this theory 
with a system of economics.

comments.author: tubertom

comments.text:
This analogy distorts and oversimplifies the concept of Adam Smith's 
invisible hand. Smith writes that the self-interest of every man will 
manifest itself in the residual betterment of that collective in which he 
resides. The concept is not exclusive of the interests of the group, as too 
often the interests of the group, as they here may directly and 
unambiguously conflict with those of the man, are best figured into the 
choices which aim to serve his own interests. One's self-interest is most 
often, as Smith repeats throughout his work, advantaged by cooperation 
within the group.  ﻿

comments.author: Jedi Force

comments.text:
+Jon Rock Actually, charity (altruism) is a common behavioral trait among 
intelligent animals, and it works brilliantly to increase the odds of 
survival among a species.  It does however cause problems in group 
cooperation when parasitism is rife within a society, because altruism (to 
increase the odds of survival) is based on the concept that everyone is 
donating to a "common pool" of resources that the community can also draw 
from.  But when one group of people is take take taking and never 
contributing to the pool, it results in a net loss, which causes other 
people to not want to donate to the pool since they feel like they never 
take from it, so why bother contributing to it?  Have you ever read 
"Nonzero: The Logic of Human Destiny" btw?  Just wondering (based on the 
way you speak).  If you haven't, you'd probably love it.  It basically 
looks at the common themes of every society on the planet Earth, what 
universal traits and behaviors all the societies share, where the 
dysfunction always seems to come from, and the direction that every society 
always seems to move in.  A great book. :)
comments.author: gobo760

comments.text:
Actually, in theory and in practice, charity -- or propping up unprofitable 
institutions, which is quite the same -- is often a nonplus for the 
investor, and is most often a net loss for the system. Charity satisfies 
the spiritual and moralistic appetite in a donor, but exists most commonly 
and objectively as a reallocation of goods and services, procured through 
extensive time and labor, which is met with no return of value to thereby 
endorse consumption at the expense of potential capital formation and net 
supply of goods and services.
comments.author: Jon Rock

comments.author: Jedi Force

comments.text:
If all men go for the blond, they don't "block each other," they fight each 
other until the victor emerges. The victor is the strongest. She mates with 
the victor. The child takes on the qualities of BOTH parents, not just the 
man. If the blond isn't mated, then she has no opportunity to pass on her 
qualities. The theory of doing what's best for the individual and the group 
presumes the blond doesn't have quality genes to pass along. And if the 3 
other men are defeated, well then, they'll go strengthen themselves to 
better contribute to the gene pool.﻿
comments.author: Jedi Force

comments.text:
I don't think you understand how genetic recombination occurs. Your genes 
do not fluctuate by a measurable degree when people "strengthen 
themselves", because the majority of changes in DNA occur by random 
mutations. Also, changes happen through DNA methylation (drinking can do 
this) or histone acetylation - in other words, people have no say in their 
contribution to the gene pool. What they can do however is practice social 
skills and exercise in order to be more appealing, but simple presets that 
leave a guy with no luck, like facial asymmetry or down syndrome, are not 
consciously fixable.

comments.author: aconroy8

comments.text:
This is not actually Nash's theory. The Nash equilibrium is a set of 
strategies for each player, such that no player, knowing the other's 
strategies, can increase their expected utility by switching to some other 
strategy. To analyse this situation mathematically, let us make the 
following not necessarily true assumptions that Nash makes in this scene: 
i) Each guy favors the blonde over the other girls. ii) If more than one 
guy tries to go for the blonde, neither guy gets anything (0 utility). It 
is easy to see then that what this movie suggests -- that no guy goes for 
the blonde -- is not a Nash equilibrium since EVERY player could do better 
by switching their strategy and going for the blonde. There ARE a few 
possible Nash equilibriums, these are when a certain guy goes for the 
blonde and the rest do not. Then anyone who did not go for the blonde would 
not do better by switching since they would get nothing. The question then 
becomes, how do we choose which of these equilibriums to go for? A simple 
and effective way is to predecide who goes for the blonde with drawing lots 
or what have you. ﻿
comments.author: bob lee

comments.text:
In the above example, while charismatic and convincing, Nash represents, as 
far as system theory goes, a form of state collusion in order to 
manufacture consent via a non-participatory, rigged system: "don't hit on 
the blonde as a whole and we all get laid."  Fine, but what if the blonde 
is the most eloquent, has the most character out of the lot? "Getting 
laid," or sex, is, here, objectified as a necessary end and misses out on a 
basic, necessary thing that we all crave: the complex beauty of process 
itself, of feeling things out.  As ee said:

since feeling is first
who pays any attention
to the syntax of things

Nash is not wrong, he is simply misguided in that he is working within the 
confines of a certain flawed system of stereotyping in order to achieve 
results themselves.  He is too concerned with the sentence or syntax codes 
of life rather than life itself.  That is his tragic downfall.﻿
comments.author: Michael Micklow

comments.text: A Beautiful Mind﻿
comments.author: Tony Palmer

comments.text:
I'm sure everyone in the comment section has pointed out problems with this 
scene. For one, Nash's theory was about the inevitable result, which very 
often is not the best result, such as the equilibrium of both players 
defecting in the Prisoner's Dilemma. Adam Smith's theory was about how 
self-interest can be merged with group interest when the right controls are 
put into place (particularly, negative results for defection instead of 
just non-reward, making non-cooperation more costly).

comments.author: Dave Friedel

comments.text:
+Logan G  I am familiar with the prisoners dilemma but to assume each 
player would have fared better is to weigh the short term gain over the 
long term objective.  Alignment through better transparency would greatly 
reduce the iterations one would have to run to achieve a better outcome.

Perhaps it would be better to think of it as Mutualism, whereby we arrive 
at a symbiotic relationship enabling us to achieve a far greater fitness 
than if it is at the expense of the other.
comments.author: Dave Friedel

comments.text:
+Dave Friedel Are you familiar with the prisoner's dilemma? If not, you 
should look into it. What bothers me about this video is that Nash does not 
seem to understand his own equilibria. In the prisoner's dilemma, 
cooperation leads to far greater rewards than competition. But this 
solution can never be obtained without playing the game repeatedly, because 
every player would have faired better if they had instead played 
competitively. Mutual competition is bad, but it's better than being the 
only cooperative player.
comments.author: Logan G

comments.text:
I don't believe each of the men could do better... But when we all work 
against each other, extreme levels of inequality materialize in the system 
- this ultimately leads to weighted biases. 

Competition only gets you so far, to reach the next level requires 
cooperation on a scale we have not yet experienced although the scale may 
be to large for Congress to influence let alone lead by example.
comments.author: Dave Friedel

comments.text:
Actually, the theory is incorrect, as Nash's friend pointed out in the end. 
Nash is suggesting an arrangement this is not in equilibrium, because each 
of the men could have done better in the proposed situation. Hence, this 
would not apply to Congress either. Every man would selfishly prefer to 
maximize his own utility over that of the group, and that is how things 
will always be.
comments.author: logantner

comments.text:
That is precisely what Adam Smith said. The problem is, that life is never 
only one dimensional there are always going to be alternative choices, and 
that is precisely what the Nash Equilibrium accounts for. This is only an 
example to a significantly more complex theory, but it serves its purpose.

comments.text:

brought to a reality by "not hurting the other girls
feelings." Instead of allowing and insisting on the less
desirable girls to "face reality" and their actual place in
this world as unalterable.
We all suffer the dire consequences for accepting lies
about ourselves and others.

Nash's theory, in practice, empowers the most bitter

deliberately restraining themselves from their natural
inclinations.
Hurting their feelings in the process because they know
they are selfish liars (they can all get laid)
Then out of guilt, allow those "settleted for" girls to act
out against the preferred females and disrupting the
natural order yet again.

Fantasies of the inadequate to have everything for nothing
and neediness as a claim to what and who they don't
deserve because of inferiorities.

Cheating for the average or leas than average person, no
matter what their numbers, hasn't worked, but it's been
fun watching them make complete asses out of 
themselves proudly assuming that God is of no
consequence and seeking to selfishly correct "their lack"
by theft!﻿
